ud8.4:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud8.4:1.3: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.
ud8.4:1.4: And those mendicants were paying heed, paying attention, engaging wholeheartedly, and lending an ear.
ud8.4:2.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud8.4:3.1: “For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
ud8.4:3.2: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.
ud8.4:3.3: When there is tranquility there’s no inclination.
ud8.4:3.4: When there’s no inclination, there’s no coming and going.
ud8.4:3.5: When there’s no coming and going, there’s no passing away and reappearing.
ud8.4:3.6: When there’s no passing away and reappearing there’s no this world or world beyond or between the two.
ud8.4:3.7: Just this is the end of suffering.”
